metadata.titleEn: Dataset of climate background and changes in China-Mongolia-Russia Economic Corridor from 1981 to 2019 (Version 1.0)
metadata.description: The China-Mongolia-Russia Economic Corridor is confronted with security problems related with global warming, mostly including the increasingly serious of degradation of permafrost and land desertification. On one hand, frozen soil degradation has caused frequent disasters such as debris flow, flood, ice and snow damage along the China-Mongolia-Russia transportation and pipeline, which will cause water and soil erosion followed by exposed pipes in frozen soil, in particular in summer. On the other hand, desertification will drive the ecological environment more vulnerable with the compound hazards of soil erosion and sandstorms occurring frequently. Therefore, this dataset will hopefully provide basic climate data for the research on the climate change and its impacts on permafrost and desertification for the China-Mongolia-Russia Economic Corridor. The original data is extracted from ERA5- Land surface climate reanalysis data (ERA5 – Land) (source: https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu). We adopted the inverse distance weight (IDW) method to interpolate the original data with the spatial resolution of 10 km. Based on this dataset, the spatial and temporal distribution pattern of climatic factors are outlined over the past 40 years for the corridor.

background: Vegetation phenology is a sensitive indicator of climate change. The advance or delay of the growing season reflects the long-term biological impacts of climate on the terrestrial ecosystem and, as a result, influences the productivity of the ecosystem. Temperature records, as well as model simulations, show that global temperatures have increased obviously and significantly, especially in mid and high latitudes since the beginning of the 20th century. Over the past several decades, both field observations and satellite records showed an extension of the growing season at regional and global scales. Remote sensing measurements are capable of providing continuous spatiotemporal information and have become the most commonly used tool to monitor the phenology variations at large scales in recent decades. The relationship between vegetation phenology and climate change has been widely documented on different temporal and spatial scales. Most studies have provided evidence that the warmer temperature unequivocally contributed to the progressive advance of the start date of the growing season (SOS) for various vegetation types over both temporal and boreal regions. In the forest ecosystem, the relationship between phenological variations and temperature has been well studied. Snow is different from rainfall as, in the high-latitude environments, thicker snowpack can insulate the soil from extremely cold temperatures and can help hold the soil nutrients, which is beneficial for forest growth.
research objective: In this study, long-term changes in forest phenology and the associated relationship with the temperature and snow water equivalent in the China–Mongolia–Russia International Economic Corridor were examined by analyzing the satellite-measured normalized difference vegetation index and the meteorological observation data during 1982 to 2015.
challenges: However, as one of the most vulnerable regions in response to the global climate change, the phenological responses and associated mechanisms in mid–high latitude forests are still not fully understood. However, little is known about the relative role of winter and spring snowpack and the possible lagged effects on the beginning or the end of the growing season in mid- and high-latitude forests. Though the changes in the end date of the growing season (EOS) also play a vital role in determining the length of the growing season, the variations in the EOS and its associated climatic driving mechanisms are still not fully identified in the forest ecosystem.
methods: In this study, we used a double logistic function to fit the time series NDVI data for each year. We used least square regression to detect the changing trend for the SOS and EOS from 1982 to 2015 at the pixel scale. We evaluated the response of spring and autumn phenology to monthly temperatures and SWE based on the partial least-squares (PLS) regression. We rescaled both the climate data and land cover data to 8 km using the bilinear spatial interpolation method to match the spatial resolution of the NDVI products.
dataset: Global Inventory Modeling and Mapping Studies (GIMMS) normalized difference vegetation index (NDVI) time-series data, derived from the advanced very high-resolution radiometer (AVHRR) from 1982 to 2015, were used to detect the phenology changes in our study area. The 300 m resolution global land cover data series from 1992 to 2015 produced by the European Space Agency (ESA) Climate Change Initiative (CCI) were used to extract the forest distribution in our study area. Mean air temperature, maximum air temperature, minimum air temperature and precipitation from the year 1982 to the year 2015 were obtained from Climate Research Unit (CRU) TS4.3 monthly data with a spatial resolution of 0.5°. The monthly SWE data in the same time period were obtained from GlobSnow SWE v2.0 data.
findings: The average start date of the growing season (SOS) of the forest ecosystem in our study area advanced at a rate of 2.5 days/decade, while the end date of the growing season (EOS) was delayed at a rate of 2.3 days/decade, contributing to a growing season that was approximately 15 days longer in the 2010s compared to that in 1980s. A higher April temperature is beneficial to the advance in the SOS, and a higher summer temperature has the potential to extend the EOS in the forest ecosystem. The preseason Snow Water Equivalent (SWE) is also an essential factor in influencing the growing season. A higher SWE in February and March and lower SWE in April tend to advance the SOS, while higher SWE in pre-year December and lower SWE in current year October are beneficial to the extension of the EOS.

Concept Completion.Question: What data collection method was used to interpolate the spatial resolution to 10km for a dataset related to climate change impacts in the China–Mongolia–Russia Economic Corridor?

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to analyze vegetation phenology in the context of climate change within the China-Mongolia-Russia economic corridor?
Example.Answer: In the analysis of vegetation phenology related to climate change in the China-Mongolia-Russia economic corridor, a double logistic function was used to fit the time series NDVI data for each year. This method, combined with least square regression, helped detect the changing trend of the start and end of the growing season at the pixel scale from 1982 to 2015.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced when studying phenological responses in mid-high latitude forests?
Example.Answer: A notable challenge in studying phenological responses in mid-high latitude forests is understanding the relative role of winter and spring snowpack and its possible lagged effects on the beginning or end of the growing season. Despite the importance of changes in the end date of the growing season, these variations and their associated climatic driving mechanisms are not yet fully identified in these forest ecosystems.

Example.Question: Could you provide an example of a dataset used to examine the relationship between forest phenology and climate variables in the China-Mongolia-Russia corridor?
Example.Answer: To examine the relationship between forest phenology and climate variables in the China-Mongolia-Russia corridor, the Global Inventory Modeling and Mapping Studies (GIMMS) normalized difference vegetation index (NDVI) time-series data, derived from the advanced very high-resolution radiometer (AVHRR) from 1982 to 2015, were utilized. This dataset was instrumental in detecting phenology changes in the study area.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the characteristics and advantages of using NDVI time-series data for monitoring vegetation phenology?
Feature Specification.Answer: continuous spatiotemporal information, monitor phenology variations at large scales, detection of changes in the growing season over time

Feature Specification.Question: What specific interpolation method is used to enhance the spatial resolution of climate datasets in this domain, and what are its features?
Feature Specification.Answer: inverse distance weighting, spatial resolution 10 km, more weight to points closer to the interpolated location

Definition.Question: How is 'snow water equivalent (SWE)' defined in climate research, and what role does it play?
Definition.Answer: Snow Water Equivalent (SWE) in climate research is a measurement that represents the amount of water contained within the snowpack. It plays a crucial role in studies of forest phenology and climate interactions, as it affects the start and end of the growing season by insulating the soil and influencing soil moisture levels, as seen in the analysis of the China-Mongolia-Russia International Economic Corridor.

Comparison.Question: How does the spatial resolution achieved by using the inverse distance weighting (IDW) method in climate datasets compare to the spatial resolution adjustments made using bilinear spatial interpolation for phenological studies?
Comparison.Answer: The inverse distance weighting (IDW) method is used to interpolate the original climate reanalysis data to achieve a spatial resolution of 10 km, while bilinear spatial interpolation is used to rescale climate and land cover data to 8 km to match the NDVI products' resolution in phenological studies.

Comparison.Question: In what ways do the data collection methods for climate background data differ from those used for vegetation phenology analysis in terms of sources and temporal coverage?
Comparison.Answer: Climate background data are derived from ERA5 climate reanalysis datasets, focusing on a period from 1981 to 2019. In contrast, vegetation phenology analysis utilizes AVHRR-derived NDVI time-series data from 1982 to 2015, and incorporates other datasets like the ESA CCI land cover and CRU TS4.3 climate data, showing differences in both sources and temporal coverage.

Comparison.Question: What are the similarities and differences between using ERA5-Land and CRU TS4.3 datasets for climate analysis in terms of spatial resolution and intended research applications?
Comparison.Answer: ERA5-Land datasets are used for climate background analysis with a focus on spatial interpolation to 10 km resolution, suitable for assessing large-scale climate impacts such as permafrost degradation, while CRU TS4.3 datasets provide 0.5° resolution climate data for analyzing phenological responses to climate change factors like temperature and precipitation, indicating differences in resolution and specific research applications.

Interpretation.Question: How might interpolation methods like the inverse distance weighting (IDW) influence the spatial resolution and accuracy of climate data collected over the China-Mongolia-Russia Economic Corridor?
Interpretation.Answer: The use of the inverse distance weighting (IDW) method for interpolation can increase the spatial resolution of climate data to 10km, which allows for a more detailed spatial analysis of climate phenomena in the region. However, this technique could also introduce biases or inaccuracies if the original data points are sparse or unevenly distributed, as IDW relies on the assumption that nearby points are more similar than distant ones.

Interpretation.Question: What potential challenges could arise from using both satellite-derived and ground-based datasets to study long-term phenological changes in mid-high latitude forests?
Interpretation.Answer: Combining satellite-derived datasets like the NDVI with ground-based meteorological observations may present challenges such as differing spatial resolutions, temporal coverage, and data accuracy. Additionally, satellite data might face issues with cloud cover or atmospheric interference, while ground-based data could have gaps or discrepancies in historical records. Harmonizing these datasets requires careful methodological considerations to ensure valid and reliable interpretations of phenological changes.

Interpretation.Question: In what ways could the variation in snow water equivalent (SWE) impact the interpretation of phenological shifts in the forest ecosystems of the China-Mongolia-Russia International Economic Corridor?
Interpretation.Answer: The variation in snow water equivalent (SWE) can significantly influence the interpretation of phenological shifts, as higher SWE in February and March tends to advance the start of the growing season (SOS), while lower SWE in April can further promote this advancement. Conversely, higher SWE in pre-year December and lower SWE in October can extend the end of the growing season (EOS). Understanding these relationships helps in explaining how snowpack dynamics contribute to the timing and length of the growing season and their broader ecological impacts.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the degradation of permafrost and desertification in the China-Mongolia-Russia economic corridor, and how does this impact data collection for climate studies in the area?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The degradation of permafrost and desertification in the China-Mongolia-Russia economic corridor is primarily caused by global warming, which results in frequent natural disasters like mudslides, water damage, and ice-related hazards. These changes also lead to issues such as soil erosion and exposure of pipelines. These environmental challenges highlight the need for comprehensive climate data collection to understand their effects on permafrost and desertification.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is the use of remote sensing measurements crucial in studying vegetation phenology and climate change in the China-Mongolia-Russia International Economic Corridor?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Remote sensing measurements provide continuous spatiotemporal information, making them crucial for monitoring phenology variations at large scales. They help in documenting the relationship between vegetation phenology and climate change, particularly in mid and high latitude regions where both temperature and snowpack significantly influence forest growth and phenological patterns.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What are the reasons behind using the ERA5-Land climate reanalysis dataset for studying climate change impact on permafrost and desertification in the China-Mongolia-Russia economic corridor?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The ERA5-Land climate reanalysis dataset is used due to its ability to provide detailed land surface climate data through interpolation methods like inverse distance weighting (IDW), allowing for a high spatial resolution of 10 km. This makes it suitable for analyzing the spatiotemporal distribution patterns of climate factors over the past 40 years, which is essential for evaluating the impacts of climate change on permafrost and desertification.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential effects on the accuracy of climate change impact analysis when using spatial interpolation methods like inverse distance weighting (IDW) for climate data?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using inverse distance weighting (IDW) for climate data, especially in a dataset with a spatial resolution of 10 km as mentioned, can enhance the granularity of spatial data, potentially improving the accuracy of detecting spatial patterns of climate change impacts. However, it may also introduce interpolation errors if the data points are unevenly distributed, which could affect the precision of impact analysis on phenomena like permafrost degradation and desertification.

Causal Consequence.Question: How do changes in the growing season's start and end dates, as observed in forest ecosystems, affect the overall assessment of climate change impacts using datasets spanning multiple decades?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Changes in the start and end dates of the growing season, as observed with advancements and delays over decades, affect climate change impact assessments by indicating shifts in ecosystem productivity and phenological responses. These shifts can highlight the influence of climate variables such as temperature and Snow Water Equivalent (SWE), providing insights into the adaptive mechanisms of forest ecosystems under changing climatic conditions.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the implications of integrating satellite-measured vegetation indices with meteorological observation data for understanding long-term climatic effects on regional ecosystems?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Integrating satellite-measured vegetation indices with meteorological observation data allows for a comprehensive analysis of long-term climatic effects on regional ecosystems. It facilitates the monitoring of phenological changes and their relationship with climate variables like temperature and snow cover, offering detailed insights into how regional ecosystems adapt to climate fluctuations over time.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the purpose of utilizing ERA5-Land data and the IDW interpolation method in developing a climate dataset for the China-Mongolia-Russia Economic Corridor?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The purpose is to provide foundational climate data for studying climate change impacts on permafrost and desertification, enhancing the spatial resolution of the dataset to 10 km and analyzing spatiotemporal distribution patterns over the past 40 years.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the significance of exploring the responses of spring and autumn phenology to climatic variables like temperature and SWE in mid-high latitude forests?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Exploring these responses is significant for understanding the phenological mechanisms in vulnerable regions, identifying climatic driving factors affecting the start and end of the growing season, and determining how these contribute to changes in the length of the growing season.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedural steps are involved in using inverse distance weighting (IDW) for interpolating climate data to achieve a 10km spatial resolution?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The procedural steps for using inverse distance weighting (IDW) involve selecting the original climate data, applying the IDW method to interpolate the data across the study area, and adjusting the spatial resolution to 10km. This process helps create a spatially continuous dataset from discrete data points by weighting nearby points more heavily than those further away.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methodological approach is taken to rescale climate and land cover data to match the spatial resolution of NDVI products for phenology analysis?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The methodological approach for rescaling climate and land cover data involves using bilinear spatial interpolation to adjust these datasets to an 8 km resolution, aligning them with the spatial resolution of NDVI products. This ensures consistency in spatial scale, allowing for accurate analysis of phenology in relation to climate data.

Enablement.Question: What methodologies enable the interpolation of climate data to achieve a higher spatial resolution?
Enablement.Answer: The dataset uses the inverse distance weighting (IDW) method to interpolate the original data, which enhances its spatial resolution to 10km.

Enablement.Question: How do remote sensing measurements enable the monitoring of phenology variations at large scales?
Enablement.Answer: Remote sensing measurements provide continuous spatiotemporal information, which has become the most commonly used tool to monitor phenology variations at large scales in recent decades.

Enablement.Question: What techniques enable the detection of changing trends in vegetation phenology using NDVI data?
Enablement.Answer: A double logistic function is used to fit the time series NDVI data for each year, and least square regression is applied to detect changing trends in the start and end dates of the growing season from 1982 to 2015 at the pixel scale.

Expectation.Question: Why might there be challenges in accurately predicting the impact of climate change on phenological events using existing datasets?
Expectation.Answer: Challenges arise because the phenological responses and mechanisms, particularly in mid-high latitude forests, are still not fully understood. Additionally, the relative role of winter and spring snowpack and their lagged effects on phenological events like the start or end of the growing season are not well documented.

Expectation.Question: Why might the integration of datasets with different spatial resolutions present challenges in understanding the climate impacts in the China–Mongolia–Russia corridor?
Expectation.Answer: Integrating datasets with different spatial resolutions can be challenging because it requires rescaling methods such as bilinear spatial interpolation to match resolutions, which might introduce uncertainties or inconsistencies in capturing fine-scale climatic impacts on the region.

Expectation.Question: Why could the use of remote sensing data be expected to improve the monitoring of phenology changes over large scales in response to climate change?
Expectation.Answer: Remote sensing data are capable of providing continuous spatiotemporal information, making it the most commonly used tool to monitor phenological variations at large scales. This capability allows for the detection of long-term trends and regional patterns in response to climate change.

Judgmental.Question: What is your evaluation of the methodology used to interpolate the spatial resolution of climate data to 10km using the inverse distance weighting method?
Judgmental.Answer: The inverse distance weighting (IDW) method employed to interpolate climate data to a 10km spatial resolution is generally a straightforward and efficient approach for spatial interpolation. However, it assumes that the points closer to the data location have more influence, which might oversimplify the complexities of climate data, especially in heterogeneous terrains or regions with rapid climate transitions.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how spatial interpolation methods can enhance the resolution of climate datasets for analysis in the China-Mongolia-Russia Economic Corridor.
Assertion.Answer: The dataset in the field uses the inverse distance weighting (IDW) method to interpolate the original ERA5-Land data, enhancing its spatial resolution to 10 km, which allows for a detailed analysis of climate factors in the corridor.

Assertion.Question: I'm not clear on how satellite-derived NDVI time-series data can be utilized to assess changes in forest phenology over decades.
Assertion.Answer: The NDVI data from the Global Inventory Modeling and Mapping Studies (GIMMS) is used to detect changes in forest phenology from 1982 to 2015, analyzing trends in the start and end dates of the growing season by fitting a double logistic function to the time series data.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure about the significance of snow water equivalent (SWE) data in understanding the forest growing season dynamics in this region.
Assertion.Answer: SWE data is crucial for understanding forest growing season dynamics as it influences the start and end dates of the season. Higher SWE in February and March advances the start, while specific SWE patterns in December and October affect the extension of the growing season.

Request/Directive.Question: Please describe the data collection method that could be used to integrate climate reanalysis data with observed meteorological data for studying climate change impacts in the China-Mongolia-Russia Economic Corridor.
Request/Directive.Answer: The integration of climate reanalysis data with observed meteorological data could be achieved using interpolation methods such as the Inverse Distance Weighting (IDW) to enhance spatial resolution. This approach allows for the interpolation of ERA5-Land reanalysis data, providing a finer spatial grid of 10 km, which can be used to analyze climate change impacts on permafrost degradation and desertification in the corridor.

Request/Directive.Question: Please outline a research approach that could address the challenges in understanding the phenological responses of mid-high latitude forests to climate change.
Request/Directive.Answer: A possible research approach is to analyze long-term satellite data, such as the NDVI time-series, along with meteorological observations. Using methods like least square regression for trend detection and Partial Least Squares (PLS) regression to evaluate climate-phenology relationships, this approach could help elucidate the impacts of temperature and snowpack on forest phenology, focusing on the start and end dates of the growing season.

Request/Directive.Question: Please suggest a potential dataset that could be used to investigate land cover changes in the China-Mongolia-Russia Economic Corridor over recent decades.
Request/Directive.Answer: The European Space Agency (ESA) Climate Change Initiative (CCI) global land cover data series, with a resolution of 300 m, could be used to investigate land cover changes from 1992 to 2015. This dataset allows for the extraction of forest distribution and analysis of ecological dynamics in the corridor, contributing to understanding how climate change might influence land cover transformations.
